Award.AwardTitle: Theta modulation of hippocampal ensembles across subregions
Award.AbstractNarration: Research on how the brain learns and remembers is crucial to basic science and to our society?s efforts to understand and treat learning disabilities and memory loss. One productive line of research has been the study of eyeblink conditioning, which shows a strong correspondence between humans and other animals in the brain structures and mechanisms involved. The hippocampus is a critical brain structure shared by all mammals that, if damaged, devastates long term declarative memory. Two patterns of hippocampal cellular activity are especially relevant local field potentials (3-7 Hz slow wave or EEG oscillations known as theta) and the action potentials of output neurons that convey the results of hippocampal calculations to other target structures in the brain. Theta rhythm is known to predict how fast conditioning will occur in rabbits and there are recent findings that it is related to human memory as well. This project uses a unique brain-computer interface that controls whether theta is present or absent during training without the need for drugs or other invasive treatments. Such training during theta is 2 to 4 times faster than nontheta. Recording from single hippocampal neurons, investigators expect to characterize the hippocampal output message to target structures and to determine how and why the message is optimal during theta. Projected results include significantly different response profiles of output neurons between theta and nontheta states, with a diverse population of interneurons related to different aspects of theta. These will be examined with respect to the improvement or impairment of behavioral learning and will clarify how the hippocampus contributes to memory. Such findings, as well as the participation of graduate and undergraduate students, suggest a broad impact of this project on scientific inquiry, student education, and the important social problem of memory impairment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the role of the hippocampus in classical conditioning of the eyeblink response. We used a brain-computer interface that allowed different animals to be trained in the explicit presence (T+) or absence (T-) of a 3-7 Hz hippocampal theta rhythm. Multi-unit tetrode recordings from the depths of the hippocampus displayed the simultaneous activity profiles of specifically identified types of neurons in subareas CA1 and CA3 of the dorsal hippocampal formation. Pyramidal cells and several specific types of GABA-ergic interneurons from both CA1 and  CA3 could be identified in vivo by their relationship to theta and high frequency ripple waves in the local field potentials recorded from adjacent electrodes. Results showed that most cell types displayed different conditioning-related responses under T+ vs T- conditions. Principal pyramidal cells in CA1 showed greater excitability in T+ during the trial periods in which conditioned behavioral responses occurred. This was the case also in CA3 but only very early in day 1 training. Inhibitory interneurons also differed between T+ and T-, as would be expected from their role in generation of theta. The most behaviorally relevant interneuron response was that of the O-LM (oriens-lacunosum moleculare) cell, which effectively suppressed hippocampal responsiveness to the conditioning stimuli in the T- group during critical trial periods. Specifically, the GABA-ergic inhibition of the distal dendritic zone of the pyramidal cells by O-LM interneurons likely prevented excitation by sensory-related input from the entorhinal cortex during the late trace and airpuff portions of each trial. Thus, principal hippocampal output neurons (pyramidal cells) were prevented from associating the tones and airpuffs, leading to impaired behavioral acquisition. Under T+ conditions, however, cells responded quickly and reliably across training and learning was rapid. Importantly, T+ and T- groups showed different cellular response profiles even when behavioral performance was equal between groups. This suggests that the hippocampus is learning different ways to support learned behavior under T+ and T- conditions, with T+ rapidly learning an optimal code while T- slowly learns an eventually useful code. In addition, when T+ animals were changed to T- after learning (and vice versa in the T- to T+ group), neither their successful behavioral responding nor cellular response profiles changed. Thus, theta contingent training appears to have its impact by shaping beneficial hippocampal responses in both principal cells and interneurons, facilitating acquisition rate early in learning and suggesting that the impact of theta is during acquisition rather than asymptotic successful performance. Our results are consistent with current models of the role of theta in hippocampal plasticity and suggest that regulating theta state, as done here with the brain-computer interface, may reveal principles of hippocampal function and lead to treatments that can ameliorate learning deficits.
